description: From Middle English pax, from Latin pax (“peace”). Doublet of peace. See peace.  As school slang, originally used at Winchester College, Hampshire in the United Kingdom.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A painted, stamped or carved tablet with a representation of Christ or the Virgin Mary, which was kissed by the priest during the Mass ("kiss of peace") and then passed to other officiating clergy and the congregation to be kissed. See also osculatory.

examples: "I say, Lu! I'm sorry I didn't believe you. I see now you were right all along. Do come out. Make it Pax."

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A crucifix, a tablet with the image of Christ on the cross upon it, or a reliquary.

description: Abbreviation of passenger. X is an abbreviation marker as in DX, TX and canx.

entries.meaning: (informal, usually in the plural) A passenger; passengers.
(informal, usually in the plural, by extension, hospitality industry) A guest (at an event or function).
(Singapore, by extension) A restaurant guest, when counting. Person.
